issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Similar problem as in RT#6626, but applies to the filenames of the untarred
image and files created at bundling time. Even though this behavior (for
bundling part) is the same as for euca2ools, the problem is more severe
because the filenames that can be used at bundling can be guessed based on the
output of eustore-describe-images, which can be executed by any user on a
machine where eustore tools are installed (or viewed by going to
http://emis.eucalyptus.com/). Probably the easiest fix is to create a
directory with an unpredictable name in /tmp, make sure it's only accessible
by the user currently running eustore-install-image and do all untarring and
bundling in that directory.
fields.summary: eustore-install-image should not untar and bundle images using predictable dir and filenames in /tmp

comments.body:
Originally posted on 2012-03-15 19:52:04 by rusvika

Thu Mar 15 12:52:04 2012: Request 6627 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Ticket created by vika.felmetsger
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: eustore-install-image should not untar and bundle images using
 predictable dir and filenames in /tmp
       Owner: Nobody
  Requestors: Vika.Felmetsger@eucalyptus.com
      Status: new
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=6627 >


Similar problem as in RT#6626, but applies to the filenames of the untarred
image and files created at bundling time. Even though this behavior (for
bundling part) is the same as for euca2ools, the problem is more severe because
the filenames that can be used at bundling can be guessed based on the output
of eustore-describe-images, which can be executed by any user on a machine
where eustore tools are installed (or viewed by going to
http://emis.eucalyptus.com/). Probably the easiest fix is to create a directory
with an unpredictable name in /tmp, make sure it's only accessible by the user
currently running eustore-install-image and do all untarring and bundling in
that directory.

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 20:01:17
The ec2 and euca2ools bundle to specific directories based on the
parameters (such as -p and -d). Is the bundling any more problematic in
this case?

On Thu, Mar 15, 2012 at 3:52 PM, Vika Felmetsger via RT <
bugs@support.eucalyptus.com> wrote:

>       Owner: Nobody

>

> Similar problem as in RT#6626, but applies to the filenames of the untarred
> image and files created at bundling time. Even though this behavior (for
> bundling part) is the same as for euca2ools, the problem is more severe

> directory
> with an unpredictable name in /tmp, make sure it's only accessible by the

> currently running eustore-install-image and do all untarring and bundling

> that directory.

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 20:10:48 by rusvika
David,

  
Yes. As I understand, by default, bundling happens in /tmp by default. It's
more problematic in case of eustore because the limited domain of possible
filenames. In case with euca2ools, the randomness of the filenames create in
/tmp is (somewhat) created by the fact that an attacker can't predict what
image (which what filename) a user is going to bundle. In case of eustore, the
guess is limited by the number of images in eustore store. So, an attacker
could pre-create files with all such names in advance in /tmp and just wait to
see which ones the user will actually use.

> The ec2 and euca2ools bundle to specific directories based on the

> parameters (such as -p and -d). Is the bundling any more problematic

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 20:10:49 by rusvika

<URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=6627 >

David,

Yes. As I understand, by default, bundling happens in /tmp by default. It's
more problematic in case of eustore because the limited domain of possible
filenames. In case with euca2ools, the randomness of the filenames create in
/tmp is (somewhat) created by the fact that an attacker can't predict what
image (which what filename) a user is going to bundle. In case of eustore, the
guess is limited by the number of images in eustore store. So, an attacker
could pre-create files with all such names in advance in /tmp and just wait to
see which ones the user will actually use.
